title: What is your favorite Beatles album and song? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: I love them all so much so this is really hard to choose…well at least for the song. For the album, my second, third, and fourth are all so close together, but my number one is way ahead of the pack. My favorite album from the Beatles is… Revolver Sgt. Peppers, Rubber Soul, and A Hard Day’s Night all come behind as albums I’d recommend, but Revolver encompasses every type of music the Beatles would ever release, and showcased every Beatle doing some their best work. For example, I love John’s “I’m Only Sleeping.” It was such a freaky song and sounded really clothe first time I head, even though the lyrics are simply about not wanting to get up in the morning. The album closer “Tomorrow Never Knows” is a revolutionary work from John, as he basically “created” psychedelic music and popularized the avant-garde sound. Ringo had what is for sure his most famous song, “Yellow Submarine,” and he has some pretty cool drum tracks as well. Paul also saw a lot of success with his beautiful ballads “Here, There, and Everywhere” (a close second on my favorite song decision), “Eleanor Rigby,” and “For No One.” I could listen to those three songs on loop for the rest of my life (Who am I kidding! I already sing them on loop in my head). Lastly, and what I consider the most beneficial sign of growth, is GEORGE HARRISON’S CONTRIBUTIONS. Please do me a favor and go listen to “Taxman,” “Love You To,” and “I Want To Tell You,” which are his three contributions (the most he ever had on one single album: the White album has 4 over 2 full albums.). When you finish listening, come back and finish reading this. Done? Hopefully you think George is so much more integral to the Beatles’ success now. These three contributions encompass everything changing about the Beatle. Taxman showcases their future revolutionary tendencies, as it was their first song involving politics (the Beatles used to be taxed at 95%; hence, one for you nineteen for me. THE MORE YOU KNOW.). Love You To is George’s first of three fully Eastern songs, and my personal favorite. It also has some philosophical lyrics. I Want To Tell You is pretty underrated in my opinion. It has some strong harmonies and I personally like the guitar sound and melodies. I still can’t forget to mention “She Said She Said,” “Good Day Sunshine,” and “And Your Bird Can Sing,” which take the heart of the album to new heights. “Got to Get You Into My Life” is a fun Jazz starter, too. The only song I don’t particularly love is “Doctor Robert.” But the rest of the album is pure genius. The last thing I’ll mention before I get to my favorite song (which will be much shorter) is that my favorite thing about the whole album is the raw beauty of the album. You can hear in the music how points it can sound so simple as a person singing with a piano (“For No One”) to something so complex like “Tomorrow Never Knows.” It also just feels like you're in the studio with them recording because they have additions like the intro before Taxman, the big chorus in Yellow Submarine, or even hearing John telling Paul to yawn in “I’m Only Sleeping.” (Trust me you can hear it with headphones.). Okay, on to the favorite song. I honestly have to go with… If I Fell On A Hard Day's Night, I personally love everything about it. The music, the Harmonies, even the voice crack from Paul in the mono mix. I could listen to that song constantly until the day I die. I hope this is interesting and I do recommend a listen to all of these songs!

What is your favorite Beatles album and why is it your favorite? This is such a difficult question because I have always had two favorite Beatles albums. (Really, every Beatle album is a favorite, because they were always the best band in the world to me). The two that stand out for me are Rubber Soul and Revolver. There is just so much original greatness on these two albums. The ‘boys’ had really come into their own on both. They were beginning their musical experimentation on Rubber Soul and they were full on into that and perfected it on Revolver. It seems as if everyone who loves the Beatles pick one of these albums as their favorite. It’s almost unbelievable how good each and every song was written and performed. They were certainly on an excellent roll! Rubber Soul honorable mentions go to ‘It’s Only Love’, ‘If I needed Someone’, and ‘Run For Your Life’…although this album is stellar in it’s genius with songs like ‘I’ve Just Seen A Face’, ‘Girl’, ‘Michelle’, ‘In My Life’…etc. You won’t want to skip any song on this album. It’s that good. Particular Revolver standouts for me are ‘I’m Only Sleeping’ (one of my all time favorite Beatles songs), ‘And Your Bird Can Sing’, ‘Taxman’, ‘She Said She Said’, ‘Good Day Sunshine’, ‘Doctor Robert’, and ‘Tomorrow Never Knows’…all masterpieces. (I also very much love the Abbey Road album because two of my all time favorite Beatles songs that George wrote and sang, ‘Something’ and ‘Here Comes The Sun’, are on that album. I think they are two of the finest songs ever written in music). EDIT: HELP! was a great album too. With absolutely fantastic songs like ‘The Night Before’, ‘You’re Gonna Lose That Girl’, ‘I Need You’, and ‘Another Girl’ it must be mentioned here as well. There are also fave classics on that album like ‘HELP’, ‘Hard Day’s Night’, and ‘Ticket To Ride’. There will never be another band like them :) EDIT AGAIN (Two questions were merged): My favorite Beatles song? I can’t choose. I have quite a few favorites. I love ‘I’m Only Sleeping’ , ‘Happy Just To Dance With You’, ‘I Don’t Want To Spoil The Party’…etc

Many people have answered this question as if it were ‘What is the best Beatles album?’ But I like it being about personal preference, because my answer is weird. I think that the most groundbreaking and most beautifully made Beatles albums are probably Sgt Pepper, Revolver and Abbey Road, but fond as I am of them, my favourite Beatles album is actually Please Please Me. Whaaaat? The early pop stuff? Are you kidding? Can't you hear that the later stuff is deeper and better crafted and more mind-blowing and… Yes, I can. I know all that, and I agree. The mature Beatles made magnificent music. I don't think that Please Please Me is even as good a sheer pop album as A Hard Day’s Night, which has a power and confidence that PPM aspires to. But, the first Beatles album is the first record I ever owned. It's a rush of raw joy, most of it torn in a single day from the hands and sore throats of a band elated at being given its big chance. Harrison can't really sing yet, Ringo is driving the bus and yelling encouragement, Lennon and McCartney are hurling themselves into the rockers and being smoothly urbane and only a bit hoarse on the softer ones. I love it more than any other Beatles album, because it made me fall in love with music. And it still has the power to do that, 40 years after I first heard it and 54 years after it was originally released.

I came to love The Beatles as a 12 year old and my favorite song and album are linked in that respect, even though they are not directly linked. As a wildly hormone stricken 7th grader, I fell in love slow dancing to Hey Jude. I remember going into a tiny recored shop in Great Falls, Montana. I didn't know the song, so all I could do was sing what struck in my mind: “Take a sad song and make it better.” The clerk plopped the 45 into the counter, and I chimed in, “The Beatles? Are they still together?” A few weeks later, I picked up Revolver, because I thought the cover was cool and I recognized some of the songs. It was the greatly flawed Capitol US version, so it was missing many great tunes, but I fell in love with tunes like For No One and She Said She Said. While I love all their output, and now I have the original UK version, not only has it remained my favorite, but I agree with those who count it as their best effort. And I still get chills when Paul delivers the first words in Hey Jude.

My favourite Beatles albums, contrary to what others believe are their best albums, are from the time when Beatles wrote poppy songs — my favourite of these being A Hard Day's Night. Why? Because they are fun, and catchy. I don't know why, I prefer to listen to catchy Beatles songs than artistically-pleasing ones. As for my favourite song, again, I'll go slightly uncoventional. My choice would be Blackbird and I Don't Wanna Spoil the Party (a tie). Blackbird is a beautiful song — let's not doubt why I rate it so highly. As for IDWSP, I rate it highly because it speaks of a little introverted guy who expects his date to turn up, but is quietly disappointed to find she doesn't come. He feels disappointed, sure, but is too civilized to make a racket and quietly departs to wallow in self-sympathy, perhaps. Sounds relatable to you? I can sure relate to that! And that somehow endears to me more than my second place-songs — And I Love Her, Here Comes the Sun, While My Guitar Gently Weeps, and A Hard Day's Night.

My vote goes to the Revolver album and the song "Eleanor Rigby."  That album strikes the perfect balance of being experimental/exploratory while being accessible and relatable.  That said, on some days I'd say the same thing about Rubber Soul -- both albums are filled with consistently high-quality songs.  The middle era, to me, represents the most mature sound of the foursome as a band.  The late era had grander expansions and indulgent experiments, but the cohesion as a unit was slipping by that point and individual voices come through more.   Which is a bit contradicting because "Eleanor Rigby" isn't exactly a band effort, either, but to me that song epitomizes the impact of the Beatles.  The fusion of highly melodic pop, relatable/universal/timeless lyrics, and classical music.  The last piece was largely George Martin (their producer/arranger)'s contribution, and I'm of opinion that without him the Beatles would not have been as significant as they are.  Simply put, the classical influence gives their songs more depth and timeless quality and lifts them above mere pop ditties of the era.  Classical music matured far earlier than other genres of music that followed, where by late 19th centuries much of tonal harmony was fully explored and the 20th century composers were venturing out of conventions and exploring more atonal and impressionistic arenas.  George Martin didn't simply slap pretty violins to play on top of sappy ballads.  "Eleanor Rigby" is a great example -- it's scored for double string quartets, a highly unusual configuration.  Notice how none of the strings double the vocal melodies, but rather they provide more contrapuntal contrast, weaving in and out, always supporting the harmony but never settling down to simply frame the chords.  This is crazy adventurous music even by today's pop/rock standards, and to pull it off without sacrificing one iota of accessibility and hookiness is a marvelous feat.  Not only is it experimental but the pieces add up to create a cohesive whole, where the whole ensemble expresses this tension-filled, intensely felt yearning.   The Beatles became what they are not just because they wrote memorable melodies that you sing along to.  They became significant because beneath the catchy choruses they relentlessly experimented and explored, and George Martin's classical influences helped them do that in a classy, authentic manner.  I wish more acts take notice of this and fuse classical influences into their arrangements.  To be fair some have gone there but they often trade in accessibility in the process.  It's a balancing act, but studying these Beatles albums help us figure out where the ideal balance may lie.

The people’s choice seems to be Revolver (I’m baffled) but for me, Abbey Road is their best and not even by a narrow margin. To summarize in five reasons, first it is the only album that I can’t find a mediocre track on. Every other album has a low point somewhere, even if the lows blend in nicely. Second, for one album and one album only a genie granted Ringo and George the power to write as well Lennon and McCartney. The George songs were his best two in his entire songwriting career, the Ringo song could have been written for him by John or Paul. He likewise never bettered it. Third, it’s the longest single player. Only the White Album is longer and the White Album is a much loved but patchy album. Fourth, it has the best musicianship and musical ideas- to name a few- the bassline on Something, the medley on side 2, the 3 part guitar solo, the 3 part harmonies on Because, the use of Moog synthesiser, Ringo’s drum solo and generally excellent drumming, the use of a leitmotif (the You Never Give Me Your Money melody reappears orchestrally in Carry the Weight) and inspired touches like Ringo singing harmony on Carry that Weight and Paul adapting a nursery rhyme first published in 1603. Fifth, John and Paul were also (still) improving as songwriters, so we also get the best version of John and Paul. And a bonus point. The sound quality and production on Abbey Road is superior to any other Beatles album, though Rubber Soul was very well produced for its day, as was A Hard Day’s Night. In short, the Beatles did something classier than they’d ever done and in many respects anything that came before seemed like them getting ready for this one moment of unadulterated pop excellence. In my opinion. However, my favourite Beatles song is I’ve got a feeling and that’s on Let It Be.

This is an incredibly difficult question to answer given the prolific nature and quality of the Beatles..  If I had to pick a favorite album, I'd have to go with the White Album because so many of my favorite Beatles songs come from there. This album shows the incredible versatility in style of the Beatles. For example, you have the classic rock n' roll feel with songs like Back in the U.S.S.R, Glass Onion and Helter Skelter and then songs like Mother Nature's Son, Dear Prudence and Blackbird to completely juxtapose the aforementioned songs.  My favorite song however, is Something from Abbey Road written by George Harrison who is my favorite Beatle. This song was solidified as my favorite after watching Living in a Material World, which is a documentary about George Harrison and the Beatles. In the documentary, they explain that although people consider it to be one of the greatest love songs of all times, it is not a song written about a woman, but rather nature itself.

RUBBER SOUL & "Nowhere Man" It's all coherent & has the same kinda tone & feel throughout the entire album. Every song works great on its own. Yet also, they flow into each other brilliantly. It's the most group-like effort to me, where they all pretty much sing together or back each other on every song. Most of these songs finally gave music & lyrics a deeper meaning instead of their "boy/girl" type songs & more introspective. "Nowhere Man"- first of all, it describe me pretty much! I like the way the song flows, the harmonies, George's guitar solo. It's got a cool groove to it. Groovy song. (I've always been torn by picking an all-time fave, but I pick Nowhere Man. Then In My Life & Strawberry Fields Forever.)    I drew that marker / pencil drawing when I was a teenager!

My answer would have to be Revolver and Tomorrow Never Knows. The reverse guitar solo and John's voice coming through a Leslie speaker with the Mellotron sound and a sitar scale describes their transition from rock to the world of psychedelia. But in second place, Sgt. Peppers and Strawberry Fields Forever (appears in 50th anniversary remix) The Mellotron in the beginning sounds amazing and the lowered pitch of John (or Paul, they sound similar, but i can't notice when pitched down) (Man, The Beatles put music ranging from casual rock: I Saw Her Standing There to the weirdest and freakiest stuff: Revolution 9) Edit: I misspelled “Tomorrow” It’s a habit that i can’t get rid of.

The Long And Winding Road is a somehow special for me.  As a teenager I was into rock (guitar) music and the style of songs that Lenon made was more appealing to me. The Long And Winding Road was kind of a transition for me to the world of pop music and I was becoming more of a Paul McCartney fan. I read some interview of Paul where he was taking credit completely for this song. He was kind of impressed with Paul and Garfunkel's Bridge Over Troubled Water and tried to make song like that when he came out with this beautiful ballad.

My favorite album is a hard day's night. I love the early mod Beatles because of the simple innocent lyrics and great melodies. Quite a contrast to some of the profanity-ridden and highly sexualized music that is more readily available to us today. My favorite song is I should have known better which is from the same album. I love the innocent and pure romance of the lyrics and how it's slightly uptempo. And I also like John's harmonica parts. An instrument that didn't get much life on their records….

My favorite album always stays the same, but my favorite Beatles song changes all of the time. The best Beatles album in my opinion is the White Album. There's just so much variety to choose from. There's good classic rock, psychedelic rock, hard Rock, soft singer songwriter, and country. Currently my favorite Beatles song is Its All Too Much from Yellow Submarine. I personally George Harrison's writing style more John, Paul, and Ringo. It's All Too Much mixes psychedelic and harder rock really well.

The Double Album Rubber Soul 1 and 2. I am kidding of course but The Beatles often referred to Rubber Soul and their next album Revolver that way. To me they represent the maturing of the band moving away from pure pop or rock and roll music to folk and country style tunes and to real experimentation with unique instruments, sounds and recording techniques. The period of mid 64 through 1966 (pre Pepper) is when they produced their most melodic, yet ground breaking works. A lot of younger fans might prefer Sergeant Pepper, Abby Road or The White Album because of their varied tunes and subject matter but to me their middle years are when the power of their song writing and collaboration really shone through.

Favorite Album is pretty easy: for me it’ll always be RUBBER SOUL. REVOLVER and HELP! would be second.and third (I prefer their middle period). Favorite Song is ever changing, right now it’s most probably WE CAN WORK IT OUT / DAY TRIPPER,

My personal favorite Beatle album changes frequently. As I purchased them upon their initial release back in the 60’s, the newest became my favorite until I literally wore the grooves out . In retrospect I feel a bit shortchanged because the British albums were far superior to what we were peddled in the US. Fifty years later now and I can’t single out one album but the three album progression beginning with Rubber Soul to Revolver to Sgt. Pepper really speaks to their growth as writers and recorders of the best music of that decade. It still amazes me that they wrote and recorded Rubber Soul in only a month.

The early stuff is great, but I enjoy most from Rubber Soul or ’65 even, through Yesterday and Today (And your bird can sing), Revolver especially, then Pepper and Magical Mystery Tour. The White Album is great but is the beginning of an individuality where when they came back here and there they seemed slicker except when going their own way. You could feel them coming apart.

The Beatles also known as the White Album. Basically you are looking at an album of 4 solo artist using the other band members as sidemen. The are some complete solo recordings as well. Paul and John both recording songs alone or with only one or two other band members helping. I think is just an amazing album. Different styles and even different producers.

Sgt. Pepper’s To me it is without doubt their greatest album and probably the greatest album ever made. It’s the Beatles in their most fearless state. Surpassing themselves and everything there was in both sound and concept. It sums up all the best of everything the Beatles did, and then more. Magical is what it is.

I like Revolver. The cover art is great. The music is from the transitional time between Beatlemania and Sgt. Pepper. They still seem to be working together very well and you can sense the change that lies ahead. It has my favorite song Tomorrow Never Knows.

A hard day’s night. For one it was the backbone to a great movie. They cranked it out on demand. And they were still having fun. It shows in songs like hard days night and i should have known better. It proved they were no flash in the pan, while their rubber soul album would take them to the next level.
Favorite Album: Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band Why: Because it's so diverse and artistic Favorite song: Back in USSR Why: Because it's so catchy
Favourite song - Tomorrow Never Knows. Favourite album - Revolver. That’s just today, though. It could be something different tomorrow.
Favorite album: The Beatles (The White Album) Favorite song: While My Guitar Gently Wheeps I guess the runner up album would be Abby Road, and my Runner up song would be Eleanor Rigby
Here are some of my favorite songs: “Eleanor Rigby” “Norwegian Wood” “Yellow Submarine” “Let it Be” “I’ve Just Seen a Face” “Octopus’s Garden” “Rain”
There’s too many to list!!! However, I probably like Abbey Road and Magical Mystery Tour the best!!!
The long and winding road. Heartbreak in high school.
